tags: sorry this turned into a big caleb rant...it wasn't planned but i can never resist sad wizard meta
summary: RE: Caleb's Devotion: I couldn't agree with you more. Unless/Until he sorts his own issues out, he will simply be drawn to them...
question: RE: Caleb's Devotion: I couldn't agree with you more. Unless/Until he sorts his own issues out, he will simply be drawn to them inexorably with a complete unwillingness to cross that line where he sees himself loved the way he unconsciously lets himself love them.
answer:
This. He’s absolutely touch-starved and affection-starved and can’t stop himself from loving people, no matter how hard he tries…but he has huge problems with admitting or expressing that love or, most of all, receiving any in return, despite needing it desperately.

I think that, in the years after the asylum, he came to realize how strong that need was, and that he couldn’t function without fulfilling it on some level. So he summoned Frumpkin. But a cat/fey familiar wasn’t really enough, and he realized this after meeting Nott. And who was Nott, after all? A goblin full of self-loathing. A thief and con artist, just like him. I think he probably told himself, It’s okay, we’re both assholes; I may be disgusting, but I can’t corrupt her too much. And we can offer each other protection and acceptance that neither of us can find elsewhere, so it’s a fair trade. I’ll let myself have this.

And when they joined up with the Mighty Nein for better protection and resources, he tried to use the same logic. Being around them so much, he inevitably started developing affection for them, which he is not allowed to do because he is a terrible person, so he tried to be like, It’s fine, they’re assholes too. We’re all just a bunch of assholes. Look at how often he described them that way to random NPCs in the early episodes! No one in the M9 has ever really intended to be a hero, but for Caleb, it’s actually necessary that they don’t think of themselves that way, because he can’t associate with heroes. He can’t count himself among them or (tentatively) call them his friends. The only people he deserves to be with, or touch, or care for, are assholes like himself.

Except that the longer they’re together, the more that justification starts to crumble. He’s seen the M9 do heroic things as well as highly questionable things. He’s started to care about the distinction. And he’s started to make distinctions within the group between people who are maybe morally murky enough for him to relate to and people who…aren’t. Just a couple episodes ago, he told Beau and Nott, “We’re the three assholes of the group”–only to have Beau argue that Nott doesn’t really fall into that category, and Caleb agreed with her. And if people like Nott or Beau aren’t as irredeemably shady as Caleb’s made them out to be, then someone like Jester (or Caduceus, or even Fjord on a good day) is so far out of his friendship league that romance is unimaginable.

But he wants it. He can’t stop wanting it. Maybe romance, definitely friendship and affectionate touch. And the more he wants it, the more he panics and pulls back, because if he ever lets himself have it, if he ever lets himself love and be loved by people who aren’t irredeemable, it might mean that he’s not irredeemable either. And that would undermine his entire worldview.

summary: 42 on your Spotify playlist, Molly/Caleb if you think it fits them or another pairing of your choice if not.
question: 42 on your Spotify playlist, Molly/Caleb if you think it fits them or another pairing of your choice if not.
answer:
Uh.  Remember that AU we were talking about a while back.  Remember how I’m like halfway through “a ghost in my lungs” and kinda out for blood. 

I should NOT be allowed to write Caleb-centric fic at 2 AM anymore, huh?

Mirrors – Pvris

standing up right above me

Caleb does not remember how he got here—here, of all places, a sweet and handsome manor in the foothills, the mountains purple and magnificent above the forest to one side, the last red and orange leaves of fall like fire around him. It’s beautiful, picturesque, the very image of a wealthy family’s modest country retreat.

The doors, oak carved with a simple arabesque pattern dripping down the frame like ivy, make sickness rise so hard and fast in Caleb’s gut that he digs in his heels without a thought.

“Hit him,” a voice says, bored, and a kick out of nowhere sends Caleb crashing to his knees.  The cobbled path hurts, and he only realizes that his hands are chained behind him when he tries to catch himself and instead lands shoulder-first on the stone.  The gag between his teeth silences his yelp of pain, keeps him from biting into his tongue on impact.  He’s not sure if that’s a blessing or not.

Lying on the stone, he tries to remember what happened.

The fight—he remembers the fight, more of a good deed than anything else, when word came down of unsavory military recruitment tactics happening in the rural townships south of Rexxentrum.  They’d spent three days asking questions and getting basically nothing before their usual stupid luck had them blundering straight into trouble.

Real trouble.

Caleb remembers the wizard, with her two bodyguards and her cold blue eyes and her graceful dancer’s step. He remembers the way her voice sounded when she said, “Is that you, my friend?”

And then he raised his hand, his fingers going black as he summoned the fire that had always served him so loyally, and she said—

She said—

His hand burned and she opened her mouth and her throat worked and she said—

His memory goes black there, as swift and clean as if it was cut short with a blow of Yasha’s sword. All that remains is the crackle of fire, and the impression of heat on his hands, and the bruises and cuts that he can feel, sprawled here on the stone path.

One has the distinctive feel of frostbite, as if he’d been stabbed with a shaft of ice through his right biceps.

Oh gods, Caleb thinks, and retches helplessly.  Jester.

“You’re a disgrace, Widogast,” the voice says in disgusted Zemnian.

“What did you do to me?” Caleb demands, lunging up—and being kicked again, in the ribs this time, to drive him back to the ground.  “What–”

What did I do?

“Get him up,” Astrid orders, and Caleb is dragged ungently up to his feet, every muscle screaming in protest.  He doesn’t fight it as they drag him inside.  He’s too busy trying to catalogue the other injuries on his body.  That gash to his thigh—could that be from Yasha?  The splash-burn on his shoulder must be Eldritch Blast, from Fjord, and the aching bruise that throbs over his ribs in time to his heartbeat…Beau.  It has to be.

Please, gods, Archheart, if you ever gave a damn, let them be okay. Caleb has that gutted, scraped-thin feeling of having burned through a lot of magic in a very short time.  All of it, maybe.

All of it, at—who? His friends?

His family, again?

He comes back to himself when he’s more or less pushed down a flight of stairs into a familiar dungeon. It’s lit only by magical glowglasses, spaced between the cells down the corridor.  They cannot account for the smell of smoke.

“Put him with the quiet one,” Astrid says.  “We’re a bit crowded, but don’t worry, your roommate is very…cooperative.”  Then she hesitates.  Astrid, of all people, who was always so sure and confident.  Who took Caleb’s mind from him with one word—what was the word—and didn’t think twice.

She walks up and rests a hand on his cheek, using her grip on his jaw to force him to meet her eyes. Caleb learned to do that here, meet eyes.  If he was going to be the pride of the Empire, Ikithon always said, Caleb had to look honest and reliable, diplomatic, and he could just have dinner when he could look his teacher in the eye and ask politely.

Astrid’s eyes are still blue and clear and cold, and she eases her grip on Caleb’s face a touch as he stares back at her.  She strokes his cheek, almost gentle.

“Don’t worry, Caleb,” she says, still in Zemnian.  “You’ll be with us again, just as soon as you’re better.  It’ll be okay.  We’re going to make it okay.”

Caleb is frozen for a long moment, half in terror and half in shock.  He can’t even articulate it because—because he just wants her to stop touching him, to stop looking at him.  Whatever she did, to take him away from himself and drag him back here, it left a feeling of bone-deep contamination in its wake, as if every small crevice he’s eked out clean of Ikithon’s influence has been dirtied all over again.

Then he hears Nott’s voice, all the way back when they first met, saying frankly, “Everyone thinks they’re real scary until they’ve got goblin teeth in their leg.”

Astrid runs her thumb over his chapped lower lip, idle and possessive, and Caleb opens his mouth and bites her as hard as he can.

It’s worth the beating, to spit her own blood back at her, and for a moment all he can think is that Molly would be proud of him.

“Widogast,” Astrid pants, clutching her freely bleeding hand to her chest and looking down at him where he’s all but hanging by the arms from the grip of her two guards.  “I’ve been waiting to have you back with us for twelve years, but I have to say I’m looking forward to making you pay for running, first.  Throw him in the cell.  He’ll live.”

Being mandhandled into the cell hurts so much that Caleb goes away again, a little bit, in a much more familiar way than before.  He lands on the ground and drags in three slow breaths, just like he was trained to, and then rolls onto his back to take stock.

He’s in rough shape, he decides.  He’ll live, certainly, but he won’t enjoy it much in this state.  At least one rib is broken.  He thinks his ankle might be as well, but he’s having some numbness that should probably worry him even more.

Maybe, he thinks grimly, he could fracture that rib properly and punch a hole in his own lung to suffocate quietly through, before she comes back.

Because, of course, he’s going to die here.  That was a given from the moment he saw the doors again.  Even if the Nein decided to come after him—and gods, why would they, he’s a monster, a rabid dog who finally turned on them—they would doubtless scout it and conclude that a half-decent wizard with a cat and homicidal tendencies isn’t worth risking their necks for.

That’s assuming they’re all still alive.

Gods, he wishes he had his cat with him.

Caleb doesn’t know how long he’s been lying there, when he feels the hand on his shoulder—an exploratory sort of poke, as if seeing if he’s bitten the metaphorical big one since rolling over.  He raises a hand feebly, trying to say not dead yet without trying to actually speak.  Speaking seems a bit outside his capabilities right now.

His cellmate—the ‘quiet one’, whatever that meant—clears their throat and says softly, “Wa-ter?”

They sound rough and ragged, like they’ve been silent a long time, and they shape the word like someone learning a completely foreign tongue, hitting every consonant too hard and muddling the vowels.  

Caleb sits up so fast he feels something in his chest crunch, and narrowly misses crashing headfirst into a magnificently curled horn.

Kneeling over him is a tiefling with skin that shows lavender and scarred in the dim light, loose shirt maybe white once.  The eyes throw the light back, reflecting red all around, without a trace of pupil, and the hand being held up as if to warn Caleb off has—oh, it has a tattoo, Caleb can see it curl around the wrist, a snake, and on the neck, peacock feathers and a hidden red eye.

“Mollymauk?” Caleb rasps.

He’s feeling a little hysterical.  Gods, maybe Caleb’s died already and this is his own personal chamber of the Nine Hells.  That sure would save everyone some trouble.

Mollymauk Tealeaf holds out a tin cup, and repeats, “Wa-ter?”
answer_abstract:
Uh.  Remember that AU we were talking about a while back.  Remember how I’m like halfway through “a ghost in my lungs” and kinda out for blood. 

I should NOT be allowed to write Caleb-centric fic at 2 AM anymore, huh?

Mirrors – Pvris

standing up right above me

Caleb does not remember how he got here—here, of all places, a sweet and handsome manor in the foothills, the mountains purple and magnificent above the forest to one side, the last red and orange leaves of fall like fire around him. It’s beautiful, picturesque, the very image of a wealthy family’s modest country retreat.

The doors, oak carved with a simple arabesque pattern dripping down the frame like ivy, make sickness rise so hard and fast in Caleb’s gut that he digs in his heels without a thought.

“Hit him,” a voice says, bored, and a kick out of nowhere sends Caleb crashing to his knees.  The cobbled path hurts, and he only realizes that his hands are chained behind him when he tries to catch himself and instead lands shoulder-first on the stone.  The gag between his teeth silences his yelp of pain, keeps him from biting into his tongue on impact.  He’s not sure if that’s a blessing or not.

Lying on the stone, he tries to remember what happened.

The fight—he remembers the fight, more of a good deed than anything else, when word came down of unsavory military recruitment tactics happening in the rural townships south of Rexxentrum.  They’d spent three days asking questions and getting basically nothing before their usual stupid luck had them blundering straight into trouble.

Real trouble.

Caleb remembers the wizard, with her two bodyguards and her cold blue eyes and her graceful dancer’s step. He remembers the way her voice sounded when she said, “Is that you, my friend?”

And then he raised his hand, his fingers going black as he summoned the fire that had always served him so loyally, and she said—

She said—

His hand burned and she opened her mouth and her throat worked and she said—

His memory goes black there, as swift and clean as if it was cut short with a blow of Yasha’s sword. All that remains is the crackle of fire, and the impression of heat on his hands, and the bruises and cuts that he can feel, sprawled here on the stone path.

One has the distinctive feel of frostbite, as if he’d been stabbed with a shaft of ice through his right biceps.

Oh gods, Caleb thinks, and retches helplessly.  Jester.

Being mandhandled into the cell hurts so much that Caleb goes away again, a little bit, in a much more familiar way than before.  He lands on the ground and drags in three slow breaths, just like he was trained to, and then rolls onto his back to take stock.

He’s in rough shape, he decides.  He’ll live, certainly, but he won’t enjoy it much in this state.  At least one rib is broken.  He thinks his ankle might be as well, but he’s having some numbness that should probably worry him even more.

Maybe, he thinks grimly, he could fracture that rib properly and punch a hole in his own lung to suffocate quietly through, before she comes back.

Because, of course, he’s going to die here.  That was a given from the moment he saw the doors again.  Even if the Nein decided to come after him—and gods, why would they, he’s a monster, a rabid dog who finally turned on them—they would doubtless scout it and conclude that a half-decent wizard with a cat and homicidal tendencies isn’t worth risking their necks for.

That’s assuming they’re all still alive.

Gods, he wishes he had his cat with him.

Caleb doesn’t know how long he’s been lying there, when he feels the hand on his shoulder—an exploratory sort of poke, as if seeing if he’s bitten the metaphorical big one since rolling over.  He raises a hand feebly, trying to say not dead yet without trying to actually speak.  Speaking seems a bit outside his capabilities right now.

His cellmate—the ‘quiet one’, whatever that meant—clears their throat and says softly, “Wa-ter?”

They sound rough and ragged, like they’ve been silent a long time, and they shape the word like someone learning a completely foreign tongue, hitting every consonant too hard and muddling the vowels.  

Caleb sits up so fast he feels something in his chest crunch, and narrowly misses crashing headfirst into a magnificently curled horn.

Kneeling over him is a tiefling with skin that shows lavender and scarred in the dim light, loose shirt maybe white once.  The eyes throw the light back, reflecting red all around, without a trace of pupil, and the hand being held up as if to warn Caleb off has—oh, it has a tattoo, Caleb can see it curl around the wrist, a snake, and on the neck, peacock feathers and a hidden red eye.

“Mollymauk?” Caleb rasps.

He’s feeling a little hysterical.  Gods, maybe Caleb’s died already and this is his own personal chamber of the Nine Hells.  That sure would save everyone some trouble.

Mollymauk Tealeaf holds out a tin cup, and repeats, “Wa-ter?”
trail.content_abstract:
Uh.  Remember that AU we were talking about a while back.  Remember how I’m like halfway through “a ghost in my lungs” and kinda out for blood. 

I should NOT be allowed to write Caleb-centric fic at 2 AM anymore, huh?

Mirrors – Pvris

standing up right above me

Caleb does not remember how he got here—here, of all places, a sweet and handsome manor in the foothills, the mountains purple and magnificent above the forest to one side, the last red and orange leaves of fall like fire around him. It’s beautiful, picturesque, the very image of a wealthy family’s modest country retreat.

The doors, oak carved with a simple arabesque pattern dripping down the frame like ivy, make sickness rise so hard and fast in Caleb’s gut that he digs in his heels without a thought.

“Hit him,” a voice says, bored, and a kick out of nowhere sends Caleb crashing to his knees.  The cobbled path hurts, and he only realizes that his hands are chained behind him when he tries to catch himself and instead lands shoulder-first on the stone.  The gag between his teeth silences his yelp of pain, keeps him from biting into his tongue on impact.  He’s not sure if that’s a blessing or not.

Lying on the stone, he tries to remember what happened.

The fight—he remembers the fight, more of a good deed than anything else, when word came down of unsavory military recruitment tactics happening in the rural townships south of Rexxentrum.  They’d spent three days asking questions and getting basically nothing before their usual stupid luck had them blundering straight into trouble.

Real trouble.

Caleb remembers the wizard, with her two bodyguards and her cold blue eyes and her graceful dancer’s step. He remembers the way her voice sounded when she said, “Is that you, my friend?”

And then he raised his hand, his fingers going black as he summoned the fire that had always served him so loyally, and she said—

She said—

His hand burned and she opened her mouth and her throat worked and she said—

His memory goes black there, as swift and clean as if it was cut short with a blow of Yasha’s sword. All that remains is the crackle of fire, and the impression of heat on his hands, and the bruises and cuts that he can feel, sprawled here on the stone path.

One has the distinctive feel of frostbite, as if he’d been stabbed with a shaft of ice through his right biceps.

Oh gods, Caleb thinks, and retches helplessly.  Jester.

summary: As much as I love the Mighty Nein I wish these chuckle fucks would realize how powerful they are.  I feel like their first...
body:
As much as I love the Mighty Nein I wish these chuckle fucks would realize how powerful they are. I feel like their first instinct is to panic. It’s understandable since they were going up against a dragon this last episode and were split, but they would have been able to take the dragon. It wouldn’t have been an easy fight but it was definetly doable with the fire elemental on their side. But instead of fighting they just teleported out of there with the plan to run away, but leaving their party behind and a dragons horde of loot.

And it wasnt just this last fight either, I mean it seems like they panic and make things worse since the started their ocean adventures. I feel like the hydra really started it, it was big and had a lot of attacks but a lot of their choices made things harder than it had to be with poor spell choices, wasting turns with gimmicks that didn’t work, and just being too afraid to take a single hit. I understand they have a caster heavy party with a lot of squishy characters but you can’t be terrified to take a hit when you have full hp. This isn’t me complaining about how they play, I get it’s their game and respect that, but they fall apart as soon as they go up against something big or are outnumbered when it’s an even fight at worst.

You can also see it during the squalleater encounter, it was hard and choosing to flee was the right choice, but Avantika and her crew weren’t nearly as a threat as they seemed. Most of them were killed by caleb alone with the rest of the Nein barely attacking and being down two characters. In a straight up fight it would have been no contest. They would have had to deal with the plank king with a different scenario but I’m just commenting on the panic they seem to go through every encounter now then the decisions they make.

The Dashilla fight is a tossup since even though the players were panicking the characters strategy wasnt bad. They would have killed Dashilla if Travis did his math right but I stand by Matt’s decision to not retcon her death, I kind of like her being the Neins unfinished business or the one that got away from them.

I just feel like there’s a panic that the players feel every encounter that wasnt there before. They’d get nervous fighting big things but it was fear and excitement they seemed to feel not dread and panic. I don’t know why, maybe it’s because they lost molly and when the risk to lose another character frightens them. Or maybe they’re still in the vox machina headspace where they were so much stronger. It’s just weird to me how they underestimate how strong they are. The mighty nein might be a group of screwups and outcasts, but the one thing we know they’re good at is fighting, even when it’s an accident they tear their enemies apart.

summary: Has there been any revealed connection between the Myriad and The Gentleman? Something in my memory tells me that he upset the...
body:
Has there been any revealed connection between the Myriad and The Gentleman? Something in my memory tells me that he upset the Myriad from their power over the Zadash underground but I could be making that up completely. 

I also can’t figure out the current position of the Myriad in Zadash and the southern Dwendalian Empire in general, because they’ve been mentioned a few times but if I recall correctly, the Mighty Nein haven’t run into them at all despite their involvement with criminal activity there.
